turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: You must not come here! How many times do I have to tell you?  If the film catches fire, runt that you are, you'd go up in a burst of flame...whoosh! And turn into a piece of...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: ...and turn into a piece of charcoal!!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: 'Cause sometimes you can't find the right place any more and so...well, actually...they stay here.  Besides, there are more kisses than you can count.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: So I can have these?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Look, Toto! Before I kick your ass all the way to China and back, let's make a deal. These strips here are yours, I give them to you. However! One  you're not to stick your nose in here any more. Two  I'll keep them for you, because you can't take them home for God forbid and save our souls, if they catch fire, all hell will break loose! OK? Oh!!! And now scram!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I bought a ticket. I've come to see the film.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Signora Maria, don't do that. He's just a kid.  And why are you telling fibs?  We let him in free. He must have lost the money inside the movie theatre...  How much did you have?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Fifty lire...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: What you find tonight on the floor between the seats?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Alfredo, did you know my father?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Of course I knew your father. He was tall, thin, pleasant, and had a moustache like mine. Always smiling. He looked like Clark Gable.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: 'I choose my friends for their looks, and my enemies for their brains...'  You're too smart to be my friend. Besides, as I always tell my kids, be careful to pick the right friends!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: But you don't have any kids!!!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: All right, all right! When I've got kids that's what I'm telling them!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I told my mother you weren't the one who gave me the films. That it wasn't your fault. But I thought you said the film could catch fire just to scare me. Now that I know, I won't steal any more from you. That's all I wanted to say. I'm going.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Toto, come here.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Now listen to what I've got to say. I took up this profession when I was ten years old. In those days there weren't these modern machines. The films were silent. The projectors were run by hand, like this, with a crank. And you wound the crank all day long. It was really rough going! If you got tired and slowed down' boom! Everything would go up in flames!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Then why don't you want to teach it to me too? Now that there's no more cranking, and it's easier?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Because I don't want to, Toto! This is not a job for you. It's like being a slave. You're always alone. You see the same film over and over again, because you have nothing else to do. And you start talking to Greta Garbo and Tyrone Power like a nut! You work on holidays, on Christmas, on Easter. Only on Good Friday are you free. But if they hadn't put Jesus Christ on a cross...You'd work Good Fridays too!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Then why don't you change jobs?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Because I'm an idiot. How many other guys in town know how to be a projectionist? None! Only a jerk like me could do it. Besides I wasn't lucky. When I was a kid there was the war! When I grew up, another war! Now it's all different. Times have changed. And you want to be a dope like me? Huh? Answer me!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Good for you, Toto. Good for you... I'm only saying this for your own good...  Cooped up in here you die of heat in the summer and of cold in the winter. You breathe in smoke, gas fumes, and earn practically nothing.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: But don't you like anything about what you do?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: With time...you get used to it. Besides, when you hear from up here that there's a full house and that people are laughing, having fun... Then you're happy too.  So I've been wasting my breath? You pretend to agree with me, but as soon as my back is turned, you do what you want!  Get out of here! I don't want to lay eyes on you again! This is the last straw! Your mother's right, you're crazy!!  But how'd he do it? The little bastard! By watching, he's learned! It's incredible!  I'm letting the box office know you're not to set foot even into the theatre! There are no more tickets for you! And I'm also talking to Father Adelfio! You won't be an altar boy any more either!!! You little runt!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Alfredo, go fuck yourself!!!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: You understand which side the gelatin's on?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: It tastes wonderful!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Will they really find work in Germany?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Who knows?...It's like an adventure.  Hope springs eternal...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Peppinoooo! Come back sooon!!  Good thing Germany's closer than Russia.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: It's got to be sent to another town. And if we don't the owner of that movie house gets pissed off.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Too bad!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Any room for me in this Cinema Paradiso?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Come in, Alfredo.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: How's school?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: OK. OK. But now that I've got a job, I'11 probably stop going...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Don't do that...Sooner or later you'll be left empty-handed.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Why? What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Toto, this isn't for you. For the moment, the Cinema Paradiso needs you, and you need the Cinema Paradiso. But it won't last...Some day you'll have other things to do, more important things...  That's right, more important. I know it. Now that I've lost my sight I see more. I see everything I didn't see before...  And it's all thanks to you, who saved my life. And I'll never forget it...  And don't put on that look. I haven't gone off my head yet. You want proof?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Yes. I want proof.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: For example, at this moment the film's out of focus. Go see.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: What'd I tell you? It doesn't catch fire!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Progress! It always arrives too late!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Chaplin's Modern Times! Right, Toto?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: That's right, Modern Times.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: I've shown it so many times I know it by heart. The first time I showed it, in 1940, was the Sunday my first wife died. They kept it hidden from me all day so they wouldn't have to close down the movie house. I only found out that night, after the last show. Those are things you never forget...  So, Toto, how are these home movies going?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: What is it, what is it? What's the picture?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: It's people in the slaughter-house killing a calf. There's blood all over the floor, like a lake. And through this lake another calf passes by on its way to die.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Now what can you see?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Nothing, there's nothing. It's all out of focus.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Is there a woman?...Tell me the truth...  There is a woman.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Yes, it's a girl I saw at the station.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: What's she like? What's she like?...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Eh! Love...what a mystery!  I understand you, Toto...The ones with blue eyes are the most beautiful. Whatever you do, you can't make friends with them.  Eh, there's nothing to be done about it! The heavier a man is, the deeper his footprints. And if he's in love, he suffers, because he knows he's up a one-way street. Because love is a meaningless thing when a man gets it into his head to do what he wants...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: What you say is wonderful! But sad...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: They're not my words. John Wayne said it in Shepherd of the Hills.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: I told you, the blue-eyed ones are the most difficult.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: But why? There must be some way to make her understand!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Don't think about it, Toto. Don't even try. With feelings, there's nothing to understand.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Stop it! I've had enough of your sermons! You act as if you created the world!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Heeey! Totooooo! Don't get pissed off with me now! Come here! I don't know where the fuck I have to go.  And the next time be careful how you talk. Not to take credit away from the Lord, but if I had created the world, in all modesty, certain things would have come out better. But unfortunately such was not the case.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: You see, it s like I say. You always have an answer for everything.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: I want to make you happy, Toto! I'm going to tell you a story.  Once upon a time a king gave a feast and there were all the most beautiful princesses of the realm. Basta, one of the guards, saw the king's daughter: she was the loveliest of all! And he immediately fell in love with her. But what could a poor soldier do compared with a king's daughter?!...One day he managed to meet her and told her he couldn't live without her. The princess was so struck by the depth of his feeling that she said to the soldier  'If you will wait a hundred days and a hundred nights beneath my balcony, then in the end I'll be yours.' Christ, the soldier ran off there and waited! One day, two days, ten, twenty...Every night she looked out of her window, but he never budged. Come rain, wind, snow, never budged! The birds shat on him and the bees ate him alive! After ninety nights he was gaunt and pale and tears streamed from his eyes but he couldn't hold them back. He didn't even have the strength to sleep any more. The princess kept watch...And on the ninety-ninth night, the soldier got up, picked up his chair and left!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No! You mean right at the end?  ALFREDO That's right, Toto, right at the end? And don't ask me what it means. If you figure it out, let me know...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Toto, are you pulling my leg or something? How is it possible to see this television without film?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Just so, Alfredo. There isn't any. And if you buy a television set, you can watch it at home, without any fuss...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Could be...But I don't like this business. It smells fishy to me.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: You weren't expecting me?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No, Alfredo, I was coming to help you...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: You were expecting her? Huh?  ...It's a nasty business waiting by yourself. In company it's better. No?...Then I'll leave.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: But where'd you go, Toto?!!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I'm here! Take it easy! Take it easy!  Sit down, sit down...  Did she come?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: No, nobody came.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: You 're thinner...You can tell you've not been treated well. .

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: They tell me you never go out, never talk to anybody. Why?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Toto, sooner or later there comes a time when talking or keeping quiet is the same thing. So it's better to shut up.  It's hot in here. Toto, take me to the beach.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Did you ever see her again?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No. And nobody knows where she is.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: It was probably meant to be like this. Each of us has a star to follow. So now what are you thinking of doing?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Listen to this one...The commander says to the sergeant: 'You remember that windmill that used to be there?' 'Yes, sir, I remember the mill's gone but the wind's still there!'  You remember the story of the soldier and the princess?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Now I understand why the soldier went away just before the end. That's right, just one more night and the princess would have been his. But she, also, could not have kept her promise. And...that would have been terrible, he would have died from it. So instead, for ninety-nine nights at least he had lived with the illusion that she was there waiting for him...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Do like the soldier, Toto! Go away! This land is cursed.  When you're here every day you feel like you're at the center of the universe, it seems like nothing ever changes. Then you go away, one year, two...And when you come back, everything's different. The thread has broken. You don't find those you were looking for, your things no longer exist. Isn't that the case?...You've got to go away a long time, for many, many years, before coming back and finding your people again, the land where you were born...But not now, it's impossible. Now you're blinder than I am.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Who said that? Gary Cooper, James Stewart, Henry Fonda? Huh?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: No, Toto, nobody said it. I say it! Life's not like you saw it in the movies. Life...is harder.  Get out! Go back to Rome. You 're young, the world is yours! And I'm old...I don't want to hear you talk any more, I want to hear talk about you.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Thanks for all you've done for me.

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Whatever you do, love it like you loved that projection booth of the Paradiso when you were little...

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Good morning, father. It's hard on the feet, huh?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Yeah!...Getting there's downhill and all the saints help you. But coming back! The saints stand there watching you, that's all! God's will be done.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: What is it, Alfredo? Right now, of all times!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Father Adelfio, I have a very serious doubt that is torturing my soul. And you've got to help me, because I've lost all peace of mind...

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: But Alfredo, what you're saying is horrifying!

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: I know. But take the-miracle of the loaves and fishes, for example! I think about it a lot...How is it possible for...

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: You understand now? You see it clearly?

turns.speaker: ALFREDO
turns.text: Oh yes, father. Now everything's clear.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: And the next time don't go around saying such heresy. You survived the fire at the movie house. But no one can save you from the fire of Hell!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: My name's Salvatore...And yours?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Elena. My name's Elena.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Hi, Elena!

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Hi. Why are you running?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No particular reason...  Nice day, huh?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Yes, nice day.  ...I've got to go now. Bye-bye.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Bye-bye, Elena.  ...What an idiot! What an idiot! 'Nice day'! Christ!!

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Father, I have sinned...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: We'll talk about that later.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: But...who...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Sssssh, Be quiet, pretend everything's normal. I'm Salvatore.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I don't care. I'll wait.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: For you to fall in love with me too. Listen carefully. Every night, when I get off work, I'll come and wait beneath your window. Every night. When you change your mind, open your window. That's all. I'll understand...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: You have a great future as a driver. If they don't arrest you first!!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: That's nothing to do with it, it's the car that's still being run in...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Elena!...But when...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I got back today. You can't imagine the excuses I had to make up to be here...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: So what'd they say?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: The army says that, as a war orphan, I don't have to serve in the military, but nothing can be done. It's a bureaucratic error. I have to leave. Day after tomorrow morning. They're sending me to Rome. But they'll discharge me ten days later. Let's go...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: No, Salvatore. You'd better go. It's my father.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Good, this way we can finally talk. I'll convince him this time.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: He won't be convinced, Salvatore. He has other plans for me.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: The son of one of his colleagues. Don't act that way. We'll talk about it later. Wait for me Thursday at the Cinema Paradiso. I'll be coming with the five o'clock bus.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: You're still beautiful...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Don't be silly...I'm old.  Don't look at me like that, please.  Why'd you come back?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Alfredo died. Do you remember him?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Of course I remember him. I'm sorry. You were terribly fond of him.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I saw your daughter. She's beautiful! Who knows how many Salvatores must be running after her...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: One or two. Bur there're not all that many Salvatores.  I've got a son, too...he's older. And you, do you have children?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No. And I'm not married.  Are you happy?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: All things considered, yes. Even if it wasn't what I dreamt of then...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: My husband...you know him.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Sure, sure! Boccia...  What's he do?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Politics. He's the district representative. We met at the University in Pisa.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: But I've never forgotten you, Elena!

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: Nor have I. Even though you disappeared...  But what's the point of talking about it? We risk being pathetic and ridiculous.  You still live in Rome?

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: It's the first time I've had to chance to tell the story. I never mentioned it to anybody.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Alfredo, damn him! He cast his spell on you too!

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: I told him I'd take his advice. But before I went away I left you that note...  I was on my way down the stairs...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Oh, how I looked for you, Elena! You'll never know. I wrote, telephoned, nothing. Nobody ever answered. But I dreamt of you for years! That's why I went away...and never came back here.  Even as the years passed, in all the women I met, I was only looking for you. I had success it's true, but there was always something missing...  I'd never have imagined that all this had to end because of the man who was like a father to me. A crazy lunatic!

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: He wasn't crazy. In the beginning I was upset. I think I really hated him. But then, with time, I understood what he said...and your silence too.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: But I never saw that note!  I must have covered it with my hand, without realizing it, that's the only explanation...

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: What difference does it make to find an explanation? That's the way it went. But Alfredo didn't betray you, he was the only one who really understood you. Salvatore, if you had chosen to be with me, you'd have never made your films. And that would have been a pity! Because they're wonderful, I've seen them all.  But you shouldn't have gone and changed your name. You should have kept your own.

turns.speaker: ELENA
turns.text: No, Salvatore...there is no future. There's only the past. Even meeting last night was nothing but a dream, a beautiful dream.  We never did it when we were kids, remember?  Now that it's happened, I don't think there could have been a better ending.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I'll never agree with you. Never, Elena.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: I don't remember him any moreMa, where's Russia?

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: It takes years to get there. And years to come back...Now go to bed, Toto, it's late.

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: I've been looking for you all day. Did you buy the milk?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Then where's the money?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Somebody stole it.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Daddy's not coming back...He's dead.

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: It's not true! No! It's not true!!! I'll show you he's coming back!

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Lia'll be so glad to see you, you'll see. And you won't recognize the kids any more, they're grown up by now.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: They're always writing to me saying they want to come to Rome!

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: See how pretty the house is? We did everything over.  If it hadn't been for you!  Come, I have a surprise....  You must be tired. If you want to rest, there's time before the funeral.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No, Mamma, it only takes an hour by air, you know.

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: You shouldn't tell me that now. After all these years!  I put all your things in here. Go in, go in...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: No...It's nothing to do with you. It's just that I was scared of coming back. Now, after all these years, I thought I was strong, that I had forgotten lots of things. Instead, I find it's quite the opposite, as if I had never left. And yet, I look at Lia and feel as if I didn't know her, and you, Mamma...I abandoned you, ran away like a thief, thought only of myself, and never gave you an explanation...

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: And I never asked for one! You have nothing to explain. I always thought that what you did was right, and that was that. With no beating around the bush...  Only one thing made me suffer: bolting the door shut before going to bed at night...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: You never used to do that!

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: Don Ciccio, I've got an idea...You remember that old abandoned movie house where they're supposed to build those low-rent houses?

turns.speaker: SPACCAFICO
turns.text: So what's that got to do with it?

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: The projector's all rusty, but I could fix it in two or three days. Give the place a good cleaning, put in some seats and bring in a projectionist and we'll show Catene in two houses.

turns.speaker: SPACCAFICO
turns.text: What the fuck you talking about? You getting into the act too, Toto? Titanus has trouble giving me even one copy and I have to say thanks! If I ask for two, the least they'll do is cut off my head and play ball with it!

turns.speaker: SPACCAFICO
turns.text: Toto, this is no film for the common herd. One day'll be more than enough...So tonight, please set up tomorrow's film, so the projectionist who is coming will find it ready.

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: OK...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: How long's it been shut?

turns.speaker: SPACCAFICO
turns.text: Six years ago this May. No one came any more. You "know better than me, Mr. Di Vita, the crisis, television, videos. By now the movie business is only a dream. The city's bought it now to make a new parking lot. Next Saturday they're tearing it down...A pity!...

turns.speaker: SALVATORE
turns.text: But why do you call me 'Mr. Di Vita'? It didn't used to be that way...

turns.speaker: SPACCAFICO
turns.text: Well, it's hard to call an important person by his first name. But if it really matters to you, I'11 call you...  Toto!...

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Mr. Bernstein, Mr. Thatcher -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: How are you, Mr. Thatcher?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's all right.  We have no secrets from our readers.  Mr. Thatcher is one of our most devoted readers, Mr. Bernstein.  He knows what's wrong with every issue since I've taken charge. What's the cable?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: The food is marvelous in Cuba the senoritas are beautiful stop I could send you prose poems of palm trees and sunrises and tropical colors blending in far off landscapes but don't feel right in spending your money for this stop there's no war in Cuba regards Wheeler.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That's fine, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I rather like it myself.  Send it right away.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: He sure did, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mr. Kane -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: That's all right, Mr. Bernstein.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hey, Brad!  Brad!  He ain't been drinking before, Mr. Kane. Never.  We would have heard.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: What does it say there?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: "Miss Susan Alexander, a pretty but hopelessly incompetent amateur -  - last night opened the new Chicago Opera House in a performance of - of -"  I can't pronounce that name, Mr. Kane.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Thais.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: "Her singing, happily, is no concern of this department.  Of her acting, it is absolutely impossible to..."

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Go on!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That's all there is.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Of her acting, it is absolutely impossible to say anything except that it represents a new low...  Have you got that, Mr. Bernstein? In the opinion of this reviewer -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I didn't see that.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It isn't here, Mr. Bernstein.  I'm dictating it.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I can't take shorthand.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Get me a typewriter.  I'll finish the notice.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I've just made a shocking discovery. The "Enquirer" is without a telephone. Have two installed at once!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I ordered six already this morning! Got a discount!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Three cents.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Two cents.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: This is all figured at three cents a copy.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Re-figure it, Mr. Bernstein, at two cents.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: All right, but I'll keep these figures, too, just in case.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Ready for dinner, Brad?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mr. Leland, if Mr. Kane, he should decide to drop the price to one cent, or maybe even he should make up his mind to give the paper away with a half-pound of tea - you'll just hold him until I get back, won't you?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: It's a saying, Mr. Bernstein.  A new broom sweeps clean.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: My Declaration of Principles -  Don't smile, Brad -  Take dictation, Mr. Bernstein -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I can't take shorthand, Mr. Kane -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I'll write it myself.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You don't wanta make any promises, Mr. Kane, you don't wanta keep.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: These'll be kept.  I'll provide the people of this city with a daily paper that will tell all the news honestly.  I will also provide them -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Let's hope they like it there.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: From the Chronicle Building that sign is the biggest thing you can see - every floor guaranteed - let's hope it bothers them - it cost us enough.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Look at that.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Say, with them fellows -  - it's no trick to get circulation.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You're right, Mr. Bernstein.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You know how long it took the "Chronicle" to get that staff together?  Twenty years.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Gentlemen of the "Enquirer"!  This has, I think, been a fitting welcome to those distinguished journalists -  Mr. Reilly in particular - who are the latest additions to our ranks. It will make them happy to learn that the "Enquirer's" circulation this morning passed the two hundred thousand mark.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Two hundred and one thousand, six hundred and forty-seven.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: But please, Mr. Kane, don't buy any more paintings.  Nine Venuses already we got, twenty-six Virgins - two whole warehouses full of stuff -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: I promise not to bring any more Venuses and not to worry - and not to try to get in touch with any of the papers -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Ask them to sit down, Mr. Bernstein.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Sit down, everybody - for heaven's sake!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: So then, tonight, we go over everything thoroughly, eh?  Especially the new papers -

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: We certainly do.  Vacation's over - starting right after dinner.  But right now - that lady over there -  - that's the new society editor, I take it?  You think I could interrupt her a moment, Mr. Bernstein?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Huh?  Oh, I forgot - you've been away so long I forgot about your joking -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It's wonderful, Mr. Kane.  Wonderful. Wonderful.

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: You don't really think so?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I do.  I do.  I mean, since you're running for Governor - and you want to be elected -  I think it's wonderful you're going to be elected.  Only -  -  Can I say something?

turns.speaker: KANE
turns.text: Please, Mr. Bernstein.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Well, the way I look at it -  -  You want to know what I really think would be wonderful?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Go in and ask him to hurry.

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Well, why don't you, Mr. Bernstein? You know Mr. Leland.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I might make him nervous.

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: You and Leland and Mr. Kane - you were great friends back in the old days, I understand.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That's right.  They called us the "Three Musketeers."

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: He's a great guy - Leland.  Why'd he ever leave New York?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That's a long story.

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Yes.  I thought it was a good idea. We've covered it from the news end, of course.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: And the social.  How about the music notice?  You got that in?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Oh, yes, it's already made up.  Our Mr. Mervin wrote a small review.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Enthusiastic?

turns.speaker: CITY EDITOR
turns.text: Yes, very!  Naturally.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Well, well - isn't that nice?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who's a busy man?  Me?  I'm Chairman of the Board.  I got nothing but time ...  What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Well, Mr. Bernstein, you were with Mr. Kane from the very beginning -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: From before the beginning, young fellow. And now it's after the end.  Anything you want to know about him - about the paper -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: -  We thought maybe, if we can find out what he meant by that last word - as he was dying -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That Rosebud?  Maybe some girl?  There were a lot of them back in the early days, and -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Not some girl he knew casually and then remembered after fifty years, on his death bed -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You're pretty young, Mr. -  Mr. Thompson.  A fellow will remember things you wouldn't think he'd remember. You take me.  One day, back in 1896, I was crossing over to Jersey on a ferry and as we pulled out, there was another ferry pulling in -  - and on it, there was a girl waiting to get off.  A white dress she had on - and she was carrying a white pastrol - and I only saw her for one second and she didn't see me at all - but I'll bet a month hasn't gone by since that I haven't thought of that girl.  See what I mean?  Well, so what are you doing about this "Rosebud," Mr. Thompson.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'm calling on people who knew Mr. Kane. I'm calling on you.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who else you been to see?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Well, I went down to Atlantic City -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Susie?  I called her myself the day after he died.  I thought maybe somebody ought to...  She couldn't even come to the 'phone.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: You know why?  She was so -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Sure, sure.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I'm going back there.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who else did you see?

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Nobody else, but I've been through that stuff of Walter Thatcher's. That journal of his -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Thatcher!  That man was the biggest darn fool I ever met -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: He made an awful lot of money.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It's not trick to make an awful lot of money if all you want is to make a lot of money.  Thatcher!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: He finished it.  He wrote the worst notice I ever read about the girl he loved.  We ran it in every paper.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: I guess Mr. Kane didn't think so well of Susie's art anyway.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: He thought she was great, Mr. Thompson. He really believed that.  He put all his ambition on that girl.  After she came along, he never really cared for himself like he used to.  Oh, I don't blame Susie -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Well, then, how could he write that roast?  The notices in the Kane papers were always very kind to her.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Oh, yes.  He saw to that.  I tell you, Mr. Thompson, he was a hard man to figure out.  He had that funny sense of humor.  And then, too, maybe he thought by finishing that piece he could show Leland he was an honest man. You see, Leland didn't think so.  I guess he showed him all right.  He's a nice fellow, but he's a dreamer.  They were always together in those early days when we just started the Enquirer.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: The way things turned out, I don't need to tell you - Miss Emily Norton was no rosebud!

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: It didn't end very well, did it?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It ended -  Then there was Susie - that ended, too.  I guess he didn't make her very happy -  You know, I was thinking - that Rosebud you're trying to find out about -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Yes -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Maybe that was something he lost. Mr. Kane was a man that lost - almost everything he had -  You ought to talk to Bradford Leland. He could tell you a lot.  I wish I could tell you where Leland is, but I don't know myself.  He may be out of town somewhere - he may be dead.

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: In case you'd like to know, Mr. Bernstein, he's at the Huntington Memorial Hospital on 180th Street.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You don't say!  Why I had no idea -

turns.speaker: THOMPSON
turns.text: Nothing particular the matter with him, they tell me.  Just -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Just old age.  It's the only disease, Mr. Thompson, you don't look forward to being cured of.  You ought to see Mr. Leland.  There's a whole lot of things he could tell you - if he wanted to.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I'm not guaranteeing a thing, Mr. Bernstein.  You people work too fast for me!  Talk about new brooms!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who said anything about brooms?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: We'll be on the street soon, Charlie - another ten minutes.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It's three hours and fifty minutes late - but we did it -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Wasted?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Charlie?!

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You just made the paper over four times today, Mr. Kane.  That's all -

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Sixty-two thousand -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: That looks pretty nice.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Do you, Mr. Leland?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Certainly not.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Isn't it wonderful?  Such a party!

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Mr. Bernstein, these men who are now with the "Enquirer" - who were with the "Chronicle" until yesterday - weren't they just as devoted to the "Chronicle" kind of paper as they are now to - our kind of paper?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Sure.  They're like anybody else. They got work to do.  They do it.  Only they happen to be the best men in the business.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Do we stand for the same things that the "Chronicle" stands for, Mr. Bernstein?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Certainly not.  So what's that got to do with it?  Mr. Kane, he'll have them changed to his kind of newspapermen in a week.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Probably.  There's always a chance, of course, that they'll change Mr. Kane - without his knowing it.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Do you, Mr. Leland?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Certainly not.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mr. Leland, why didn't you go to Europe with him?  He wanted you to.  He said to me just yesterday -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: I wanted him to have fun - and with me along -

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Mr. Bernstein, I wish you'd let me ask you a few questions, and answer me truthfully.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Don't I always?  Most of the time?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: Mr. Bernstein, am I a stuffed shirt? Am I a horse-faced hypocrite?  Am I a New England school-marm?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: If you thought I'd answer different from what Mr. Kane tells you - well, I wouldn't.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Well, he'll be coming back in September. The Majestic.  I got the reservations. It gets in on the ninth.

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: September the ninth?

turns.speaker: LELAND
turns.text: What's happened?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I'm all right, Mr. Leland.  Only there was some fellows out front that thought they ought to take things up with me.  I learned 'em! Didn't I, officer?
